description.center: The Cache is located in The grounds of Kenure Park

long-description.p: For centuries Kenure House and its woodland dominated the skyline and the life of nearby Rush. Not that the inhabitants of Rush were ever fully dominated by any great landowners, whoever they might be. Having made their living for centuries from the sea and from the fertile land of the region, their relationship with their great landowners was a respectfully independent one. As far back as the early 16th Century, the fishermen of Rush exhorted the owners of Kenure to secure a safe harbour for their boats, saying that otherwise they would have to seek employment elsewhere and "no longer dwell in this habitation".

In 1964 the contents of Kenure House were auctioned, and the estate, which was also known as Kenure Park, was sold to the Irish Land Commission. Colonel R. H. Fenwick-Palmer, the last of the Palmers to live in the house, had decided to abandon the losing battle against rising costs, dry rot and rising damp. Within a short while the house was handed over to Dublin County Council, who, unable to find a buyer for it, in its increasingly dilapidated and vandalized condition, were finally obliged to demolish it for safety reasons in 1978.

The tragedy of the demise of Kenure House is that the house, walled gardens and woodland, were equal, if not superior, in architecture, natural beauty and history, to other estates in the Fingal area, estates like Ardgillan or New bridge House, which have since been acquired as public amenities. The sale of Kenure House by the Palmer family came that few years too early for such enlightened planning.

The development of St.Catherine's housing estate on the site of the house and much of the park has brought new blood to the town of Rush. The strange sight of an enormous portico puzzles many people, standing as it does, alone against the sky. (At the time of its demolition, a number of Rush people did protest, and managed to prevent at least the portico from being destroyed.) People ask themselves what was the house itself like, who were the privileged ones who trod its halls, or drove their carriages along its avenues?

Traces of a ruined castle which perhaps predate the later Norman dwellings can be seen near the cache location. However, it is since Norman times, when Ireland was divided up as payments to Henry II's Norman lords, that we have a clearer picture of Kenure's past.

At the above location take note of the round pillars of the portico call this number A
Also take note of the number of square pillars of the portico call this number B
The Cache is located at N53 3B.(A-B)/2(A-B)/2 7 W6 05.(A-B)(A-B)0
Please re hide the cache with care to prevent young muggles from finding it

ul.li:
2010-03-20T19:00:00Z : Found it by CheekyCheetah
Found when out with my parents (Frezeluberz), gilliancclarke (& sprogs) and Zoe andDaddy TFTC

2010-03-20T19:00:00Z : Found it by WeeBookWorm
Found when out with my parents (Frezeluberz), gilliancclarke (& sprogs) and Zoe andDaddy TFTC

2010-03-20T19:00:00Z : Found it by gilliancclarke
Eventually convinced to do this one but there was alot of muttering under my breath.....

2010-03-20T19:00:00Z : Found it by Zoe andDaddy
Found while out with Gilliancclarke, Frezeluberz and the kids.
I would have loved to see this building in all its glory. Had to hunt or the caches.
Thanks.

2010-03-20T19:00:00Z : Found it by Frezeluberz
I agree with medic143 ... coords out a bit - but not by too much. A year since it was last found - I love getting caches like this :) We did find the portico a strange sight to behold sitting there all alone. Must have been quite some home to live in. Took a bit of a hunt after giving the kids time to play in the playground. The weather was great today - who said it was going to rain?! Gotta say one thing though - getting Zoe andDaddy & gilliancclarke to do multis is a nightmare!! I don't think they like them much! Especially your ambiguous ones ... not this one!! Your ambiguous ones!! TFTC.
[This entry was edited by Frezeluberz on Monday, March 22, 2010 at 3:06:58 AM.]

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Kenure House
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: The Cache is located in The grounds of Kenure Park
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Kenure House and Demesne

For centuries Kenure House and its woodland dominated the skyline and the life of nearby Rush. Not that the inhabitants of Rush were ever fully dominated by any great landowners, whoever they might be. Having made their living for centuries from the sea and from the fertile land of the region, their relationship with their great landowners was a respectfully independent one. As far back as the early 16th Century, the fishermen of Rush exhorted the owners of Kenure to secure a safe harbour for their boats, saying that otherwise they would have to seek employment elsewhere and "no longer dwell in this habitation".

In 1964 the contents of Kenure House were auctioned, and the estate, which was also known as Kenure Park, was sold to the Irish Land Commission. Colonel R. H. Fenwick-Palmer, the last of the Palmers to live in the house, had decided to abandon the losing battle against rising costs, dry rot and rising damp. Within a short while the house was handed over to Dublin County Council, who, unable to find a buyer for it, in its increasingly dilapidated and vandalized condition, were finally obliged to demolish it for safety reasons in 1978.




The tragedy of the demise of Kenure House is that the house, walled gardens and woodland, were equal, if not superior, in architecture, natural beauty and history, to other estates in the Fingal area, estates like Ardgillan or New bridge House, which have since been acquired as public amenities. The sale of Kenure House by the Palmer family came that few years too early for such enlightened planning.


The development of St.Catherine's housing estate on the site of the house and much of the park has brought new blood to the town of Rush. The strange sight of an enormous portico puzzles many people, standing as it does, alone against the sky. (At the time of its demolition, a number of Rush people did protest, and managed to prevent at least the portico from being destroyed.) People ask themselves what was the house itself like, who were the privileged ones who trod its halls, or drove their carriages along its avenues?

Traces of a ruined castle which perhaps predate the later Norman dwellings can be seen near the cache location. However, it is since Norman times, when Ireland was divided up as payments to Henry II's Norman lords, that we have a clearer picture of Kenure's past.

The Cache

At the above location take note of the round pillars of the portico call this number A
Also take note of the number of square pillars of the portico call this number B

The Cache is located at N53 3B.(A-B)/2(A-B)/2 7 W6 05.(A-B)(A-B)0

Please re hide the cache with care to prevent young muggles from finding it


The Windsockers
